messageBody:
This is very cool. No need even to override runTest(), which is nice.

I would suggest two things:

1. Use System.getProperty(name, defaultValue) to make it easier to
understand what's going wrong when those properties are not provided.

2. Ensure that your XmlMessageTest and SoapMessageTest have good names
-- by which I mean that their constructors put together a good name for
each test. Something like "XMLTest@http://servername:port/file".

But very cool. It's simple, but very flexible.

So said Mark Derricutt on 2/18/2003 --------------------

>On Monday, February 17, 2003 15:29:09 -0500 "J. B. Rainsberger"
><jbr@...> wrote:
>
>> I think I wrote this up in another message in this group. You should
be
>> able to adapt the solution to your situation.
>
>I ended up reworking my TestCase and changed my suite() to be:
>
> public static Test suite() {
> TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
>
> String pathName = System.getProperty("test.path");
> String hostName = System.getProperty("test.host");
> String hostPort = System.getProperty("test.port");
>
> System.out.println("Running test messages from: " + pathName
);
> File path = new File( pathName );
> File[] files = path.listFiles();
>
> for (int i = 0; i < files.length; i++) {
> File file = files[i];
> if ( file.getName().startsWith("test") &&
>file.getName().endsWith("xml")) {
> suite.addTest( new XmlMessageTest( "http", hostName,
>hostPort, file ));
> suite.addTest( new XmlMessageTest( "https", hostName,
>hostPort, file ));
> suite.addTest( new SoapMessageTest( "http", hostName,
>hostPort, file ));
> suite.addTest( new XmlMessageTest( "https", hostName,
>hostPort, file ));
> }
> }
>
> return suite;
> }
>
>
>Seems to be working fine.
